    "consider the sphere and a chosen rotational action generated by @xmath4 : @xmath5    let @xmath6 , @xmath7 , and let @xmath8 be the @xmath9 normalized spherical harmonics , the joint eigenfunctions of the laplacian in spherical coordinates @xmath10 and the rotational generator @xmath11 : @xmath12    applied to the sphere , our main result on weighted @xmath13 estimates reads    [ t : sph ] let @xmath14 , @xmath15 , @xmath16 , be the spherical harmonics defined above .",
    "then for @xmath17 , @xmath18 where @xmath19 is a universal constant .    the power @xmath20 in can be explained as follows .",
    "taking the fourier expansion in @xmath21 reduces the first differential equation in   to @xmath22 where @xmath23 is an eigenvalue of @xmath24 and @xmath25 .",
    "when @xmath26 is such that @xmath27 , this equation has two turning points at @xmath28 .",
    "physically this corresponds to caustic formation : the focusing at turning points increases the intensity of the wave function , that is , it increases its @xmath29 norm by a factor of @xmath30   see proposition [ l : well - eig ] below .",
    "factor can be seen on the model example of the equation @xmath31 , with a turning point at @xmath32 and locally @xmath9-normalized solution @xmath33 , where @xmath34 is the airy function .",
    "the @xmath35 normalization here follows from the asymptotic behavior of @xmath36 as @xmath37 . ]",
    "since the @xmath35 loss happens all over the sphere , such growth in the @xmath29 norm can not be eliminated by a weight function . in order to get a uniform bound on the entire sphere in , we choose a weight function vanishing at the pole and the equator . a more detailed explanation of the weights and the principles of semiclassical analysis on which the analysis is based is given at the end of section  [ wee ] .",
    "consider functions on the sphere which are _ bandlimited _ and _ sparse _ : @xmath38 functions well - approximated as bandlimited and sparse arise in applications ranging from models for protein structure @xcite to cosmic microwave background ( cmb ) data @xcite . in @xcite ,",
    "rauhut and ward showed that such functions can be efficiently reconstructed from far less information than their ambient dimension suggests ; in particular , they show that for certain sets of sampling points @xmath39,$ ] of size @xmath40 any function @xmath41 of the form can be reconstructed from its values @xmath42 as the function of this bandwidth whose coefficient vector @xmath43 has minimal @xmath44-norm @xmath45 .",
    "it is shown that @xmath46 angular coordinates @xmath47 where @xmath46 satisfies , drawn independently from the measure @xmath48 on @xmath49 \\times [ 0,2\\pi]$ ] , will almost always be a set of sampling points for which this holds .    in section @xmath50",
    "we show how theorem [ t : sph ] improves on the results in @xcite , strengthening the required number of sampling points for recovering functions of the form to @xmath51 by drawing angular coordinates @xmath47 independently from the measure @xmath52 on @xmath49 \\times [ 0,2\\pi]$ ] .",
    "the specific statement is given in corollary [ cor3 ] .",
    "as seen in figure  [ fig:1a](c ) , this measure generates higher sampling density around the poles and equator ; the measure @xmath48 , illustrated in figure [ fig:1a](b ) and on which the analysis of @xcite is based , only generates higher sampling density at the poles .",
    "it remains open whether there exists a sampling strategy for which the factor of @xmath53 in can be provably eliminated .",
    "as the discussion following theorem 1 indicates , such a result can not be done by using weight functions alone .",
    "the weighted @xmath13 estimates given in corollary  [ cor2 ] of section  [ wee ] provide sampling strategies more broadly for recovering sparse eigenfunction expansions on any strictly convex surface of revolution",

    "the phase diagrams in figure [ fig:1 ] correspond to sampling measures ( a ) @xmath90 , ( b ) @xmath48 , and ( c ) @xmath91 .",
    "white indicates complete recovery , and black indicates no recovery whatsoever .",
    "it is clear that the sampling strategies @xmath92 or @xmath93 give better results than @xmath94 .",
    "diagrams ( b ) and ( c ) both show a sharp transition between complete recovery and no recovery whatsoever as the ratio @xmath95 increases as a function of @xmath96",
    ". however , the region of phase space corresponding to complete recovery is noticeably larger in ( 3 ) when @xmath96 is large .",
    "note that when @xmath97 , all three sampling schemes should give perfect reconstruction as the system of equations @xmath98 in the minimization problem has a unique solution with probability @xmath87 .",
    "however , plots ( a ) and ( b ) show zero reconstruction around this point , an artifact of round - off error due to the ill - conditioning of the sampling matrix @xmath72 .     of sparsity level @xmath99 from @xmath46 samples",

    "we then show how the main results of this paper strengthen and generalize existing sparse recovery bounds .",
    "the generalization of theorem [ t : sph ] to arbitrary convex surfaces of revolution is given in theorem [ t:1 ] of section [ wee ] , while section [ prel ] provides a detailed account of preliminaries from semiclassical analysis needed for the proof which is presented in section  [ proo ] .",
    "* notation . * in the paper @xmath19 denotes a constant , independent of asymptotic parameters , but changing depending on the context .",
    "we use the usual @xmath103 notation with subscripts to indicate that the associated constant might depend on the variable in the subscript , for instance @xmath104 means that @xmath105 for some @xmath106 depending on @xmath107 .",
    "we follow the basic notational convention listed in ( * ? ? ?",
    "* appendix a ) .",
    "consequently the above notation should not be confused with @xmath108 for @xmath109 a hilbert space ; the latter means that @xmath110 .",
    "the notation @xmath111 means that there exists @xmath112 such that @xmath113 .",
    "finally , we use the shorthand @xmath89 = \\{1,2 , ... , n\\}$ ] . for a vector @xmath114 or @xmath115",
    ", we indicate the size of the support of by @xmath116 .",
    "suppose we have a finite system of functions @xmath117 \\}$ ] on a compact manifold @xmath54 .",
    "suppose we also have a function @xmath118 which is @xmath1-sparse with respect to this function system , @xmath119 the area of compressed sensing @xcite is concerned with the following questions .",
    "for a given system @xmath120 and @xmath1-sparse function @xmath41 of the form , how many samples @xmath121 where @xmath122 do we need to uniquely identify @xmath41 ?",
    "is it possible moreover to efficiently and robustly reconstruct such a function from these samples ? that is , to distinguish an arbitrary linear combination of @xmath2 known functions @xmath64 we would clearly need @xmath2 samples .",
    "but if we know a priori that @xmath41 is @xmath1-sparse , and if the locations of the @xmath1 nonzero coefficients @xmath123 are known , then we would need only @xmath1 samples .",
    "when the locations of the @xmath1 coefficients are not known , @xmath124 samples still suffice in certain situations .",
    "namely , consider the matrix @xmath125 with entries @xmath126 , and observe that @xmath127 each @xmath1-sparse function @xmath41 has a distinct image @xmath128 if every sub - matrix of the @xmath129 matrix @xmath130 consisting of at most @xmath124 columns is non - singular , and this is true for many @xmath71 matrices having only @xmath131 rows ( consider matrices having i.i.d .",
    "gaussian entries , for example . )",
    "subject to this condition , one could solve for the unique @xmath1-sparse solution to @xmath128 by searching over all @xmath1-sparse vectors @xmath132 .",
    "however , in general this is an np - hard problem . as it turns out , polynomial - time recovery of sparse solutions is possible if all @xmath124-column sub - matrices of @xmath130 are not only nonsingular , but well - conditioned - a property that can only hold if @xmath130 has at least @xmath133 rows @xcite . in the compressed sensing literature ,",
    "a matrix @xmath125 is said to have the _ restricted isometry property _ of order @xmath124 if , for a fixed parameter @xmath134 , @xmath135 as shown in @xcite , if a matrix @xmath136 has this property , and if @xmath128 for some @xmath1-sparse vector @xmath137 , then @xmath132 is guaranteed to also be the vector of minimal @xmath44-norm among solutions @xmath138 to the underdetermined system @xmath139 .",
    "as @xmath44-minimization can be solved efficiently using linear programming , the sparse coefficient vector @xmath132 can be reconstructed efficiently .",
    "moreover , given any arbitrary vector @xmath140 with _",
    "best @xmath1-sparse approximation error _ @xmath141 and the minimizing solution @xmath142 then @xmath143 .",
    "in general it is hard to verify the restricted isometry property holds for a given matrix @xmath130 , but in the following set - up it can be assured with high probability .",
    "suppose we have a system of functions @xmath144 , @xmath145 \\}$ ] which are orthonormal on a measurable space @xmath146 endowed with a probability measure @xmath147 , i.e. @xmath148.\\ ] ] suppose further that @xmath46 sampling points @xmath122 are drawn independently from the orthogonalization measure @xmath147 .",
    "then , as shown in @xcite , with high probability with respect to the draw of the sampling points , the normalized sampling matrix @xmath149 , where @xmath126 , satisfies as long as the number of samples @xmath150 , where @xmath151 the parameter @xmath152 should be interprested as a measure of _ incoherence _ between the basis @xmath64 and pointwise measurements ; the smaller @xmath152 , the fewer number @xmath46 of sampling points @xmath153 are needed to recover sparse expansions . this can be interpreted as a discrete heisenberg uncertainty principle @xcite .",
    "a precise statement follows .",

    ", we see that @xmath167 sampling points drawn independently from the uniform measure on @xmath168 $ ] will be sufficient to identify any @xmath1-sparse trigonometric polynomial of degree at most @xmath2 .",
    "the complex exponentials are eigenfunctions of the laplacian on the circle .",

    "proposition [ thm : bos2 ] quantifies the link between weighted @xmath13 estimates on orthonormal function systems and sparse recovery guarantees . for the legendre polynomials , which satisfy the weighted @xmath13 estimate @xmath203 proposition [ thm : bos2 ]",
    "gives that @xmath204 sampling points from the _ chebyshev _ measure @xmath205 are sufficient for recovering @xmath1-sparse expansions in the first @xmath2 legendre polynomials . for details , see @xcite .",
    "below we summarize how the weighted @xmath13 estimates of this paper improve and generalize previous results and give rise to proposition  [ theo : sphere ] .    1 .   in @xcite",
    ", krasikov proves the following weighted @xmath13 estimate for the spherical harmonics @xmath206 : @xmath207 this estimate implies @xmath208 in @xcite , the authors apply proposition [ thm : bos2 ] using this estimate to conclude that @xmath209 sampling points on the sphere with angular coordinates @xmath47 drawn independently from the measure @xmath48 on @xmath49 \\times [ 0,2\\pi)$ ] suffice for recovering bandlimited sparse spherical harmonic expansions of the form .",
    "this improved on the @xmath210 required sampling points given by corollary [ cor1 ] , if sampling points are drawn i.i.d . from the uniform distribution on the sphere .",
    "2 .   the weighted @xmath13 estimate given in theorem [ t : sph ] provides even stronger sparse recovery guarantees for spherical harmonic expansions .",
    "corollary [ cor3 ] results from applying this estimate to proposition [ thm : bos2 ] : @xmath3 sampling points @xmath47 from the measure @xmath211 suffice for recovering sparse bandlimited spherical harmonic expansions .",
    "as summarized in proposition [ theo : sphere ] , the weighted @xmath13 estimate of corollary [ cor2 ] gives rise to more general sampling strategies for recovering sparse eigenfunction expansions on strictly convex surfaces of revolution .",

    "proposition  [ l : cutoff ] implies that , if we want to obtain weighted @xmath0 ( or any other local ) estimates on every function @xmath225 satisfying   , it is enough to cover @xmath54 by open sets invariant under rotation ( which we will call bands ) and prove the estimates for functions supported in each of these bands . the next result provides weighted @xmath0 estimates for three common types of behavior of the metric in bands :    [ t:1 ] let @xmath248 be a band given by one of the three cases below ; the small parameter @xmath249 characterizes the width of this band .",

    "the corresponding estimates are latexmath:[\\[\\begin{gathered } \\label{e : pole - est-1 }    \\label{e : pole - est-2 }     * remark .",
    "* the metric of a surface of revolution can be brought locally to the form   or  , with @xmath255 , with no conditions on the derivatives of @xmath254 .",
    "indeed , away from the poles ( points on the surface lying on the axis of rotation ) , the metric has the form @xmath266 where @xmath267 is the projection onto the axis of rotation and @xmath268 is a positive function giving the profile of the surface . making a change of variables @xmath269 with @xmath270 , we bring the metric to the form  .",

    "we obtain the following corollary for convex surfaces of revolution .",

    "suppose that @xmath275 then , @xmath276    the riemannian volume measure on @xmath277 is given by @xmath278 which means that the sampling measure based on should be given by @xmath279 here @xmath280 is the replacement for @xmath281 .",
    "the constant @xmath282 in is given by @xmath283    theorem  [ t:1 ] does not cover the case of a band with metric of the form   and @xmath258 , @xmath284 ; in particular , it does not apply to the case of a hyperbolic equator , when @xmath259 .",
    "this case does not occur for convex surfaces considered here .",
    "let us give an informal explanation of the estimates in theorem  [ t:1 ] .",
    "by considering an eigenfunction decomposition of @xmath225 , we can reduce to the case when @xmath225 is an exact joint eigenfunction of @xmath285 and @xmath286 , rather than a function satisfying  . using semiclassical analysis",
    "( see  @xcite for the general theory and the references below for specific facts we will be using ) , we can relate the behavior of the ` quantum ' object @xmath225 for small values of the ` planck constant ' @xmath239 to the corresponding ` classical ' integrable hamiltonian system given by the principal symbols @xmath287 and @xmath288 of @xmath285 and @xmath286 , respectively .",
    "the principal symbol of a differential operator is a polynomial ( on each fiber ) function on the cotangent bundle @xmath289 , obtained formally by replacing each instance of @xmath290 by the corresponding momentum @xmath291 , and then discarding the terms of higher order in @xmath239 . in our situation , @xmath287 is the square of the norm induced by @xmath254 on the cotangent bundle and @xmath288 is the momentum corresponding to @xmath292 .",
    "the function @xmath225 will then be concentrated , or microlocalized , on the set @xmath293 one can in fact approximate @xmath225 by certain explicit highly oscillating integral expressions up to an @xmath294 error ; our analysis would consist of studying the asymptotic behavior of these integrals as @xmath295 .",
    "the set @xmath296 consists of unit geodesics with prescribed angular momentum ( that is , of rotations of one such geodesic ) ; there are two possibilities :    1 .",
    "@xmath296 is a lagrangian torus ; 2 .",
    "@xmath296 is a circle corresponding to an equator .    in case",
    "( 1 ) , @xmath225 is a lagrangian distribution associated to @xmath296   that is , it can be written as a finite sum of expressions of the wkb form  , with @xmath297 locally parametrizing the lagrangian @xmath296 and @xmath298 some smooth symbol   see section  [ s : lagr ] for details .",
    "the @xmath0 norm of @xmath225 corresponds to how well @xmath296 projects onto the base space @xmath54 . at a point where the tangent space of @xmath296 projects surjectively onto @xmath54 , the @xmath0 norm of @xmath225 is @xmath299 .",
    "the only other possibility that could arise in the regular case is a turning point ; that is , a point where the function @xmath300 has a nondegenerate critical point when restricted to a geodesic ( for the sphere , these are the points of maximal and minimal latitude on a given great circle ) .",
    "the behavior of @xmath225 near the turning points is similar to that of the airy function , and its @xmath0 norm is of order @xmath35 by a variant of van der corput s lemma .",
    "if one is unfamiliar with lagrangian distributions , the simple model case to consider would be the eigenfunctions of the laplacian @xmath301 on the circle @xmath302 .",
    "those are given by @xmath303 , with the eigenvalue @xmath304 .",
    "( note that only a discrete set of @xmath170 is possible here   this is a baby version of the quantization condition mentioned in the next section . )",
    "the corresponding symbol is @xmath305 and the corresponding lagrangian would be @xmath306 ; it projects surjectively onto the @xmath307 variables , which corresponds to the fact that we do not need any integration variables @xmath308 in the formula   to define eigenfunctions , and to the fact that the @xmath0 norm of eigenfunctions is bounded by a constant .    for @xmath309 ,",
    "a new kind of problem arises   the intersection of @xmath296 with the fiber of @xmath289 at a pole is a not a point , but a circle consisting of all unit covectors at the pole , leading to a loss of @xmath310 in the @xmath0 norm .",
    "this problem disappears and we get back the @xmath311 estimate if either @xmath26 is away from zero or we are away from the pole , which is reflected in  . if @xmath309 , the turning points are located at the poles ; therefore , away from the poles we get an @xmath299 estimate .",
    "the blow - up rate of this estimate as we approach a pole is quantified by  .    in case",
    "( 2 ) we can separate out the @xmath292 variable ( as @xmath296 does not pass through any poles ) and obtain a one - dimensional problem ; then @xmath225 is a low - lying eigenfunction of a schrdinger operator with a potential well .",
    "the bottom of the well eigenfunctions ( those with @xmath312 ) are approximated by the gaussian @xmath313 ; we see that they are @xmath314 this explains the first part of   and",
    ". however , if @xmath315 is bounded away from zero , we are away from the equator and thus back to case ( 1 ) , which explains the @xmath35 term in  .",
    "in this subsection , we briefly review the local theory of semiclassical lagrangian distributions ; see for example @xcite , ( * ? ? ? * chapter  6 ) , ( * ? ? ? * chapter  8) or  ( * ? ? ?",
    "* section  2.3 ) for a detailed account , and  ( * ? ? ?",
    "* section  25.1 ) or  ( * ? ? ?",
    "* chapter  11 ) for the presentation in the closely related microlocal case .",
    "assume that @xmath316 is a manifold and @xmath297 is a smooth real - valued function defined on an open set @xmath317 . define the critical set @xmath318 by @xmath319 the function @xmath320 is called a ( nondegenerate ) phase function , if for each @xmath321 , the differentials @xmath322 are linearly independent at @xmath323 .",
    "if this is the case , the set @xmath324 is an ( immersed ) lagrangian submanifold .",
    "we say that @xmath320 generates @xmath325 ; in general , if @xmath326 is a lagrangian submanifold and @xmath327 , then we say that @xmath320 generates @xmath296 near @xmath328 . for each lagrangian submanifold @xmath296 and each @xmath329",
    ", there exists a phase function generating @xmath296 near @xmath328 ; however , such phase function is not unique .",
    "if @xmath326 is an ( embedded ) lagrangian submanifold , @xmath320 is a phase function generating @xmath296 near some point , and @xmath330 is bounded in @xmath331 uniformly in @xmath239 , we can define the @xmath239-dependent family of smooth functions @xmath332 here the factor @xmath333 is chosen so that @xmath334 is bounded by a certain @xmath335 seminorm of @xmath298 and equivalent to the @xmath9 norm of @xmath336 , modulo @xmath337 terms .",
    "we call @xmath338 a ( semiclassical compactly microlocalized ) lagrangian distribution associated to @xmath296 .",
    "this family is microlocalized on @xmath325 in the following sense : @xmath339 more generally , we call @xmath338 a lagrangian distribution associated to @xmath296 , if it is the sum of finitely many expressions of the form  , for different phase functions parametrizing @xmath296 , and an @xmath340 remainder .    if @xmath338 is a lagrangian distribution associated to @xmath296 , @xmath320 is a phase function generating @xmath296 , and @xmath225 is microlocalized in a compact subset of @xmath325 , then we can always write @xmath225 in the form   for some amplitude @xmath298 modulo an @xmath341 remainder .",
    "( the general case can always be reduced to this one by a microlocal partition of unity , if we know enough phase functions to cover the whole @xmath296 . ) in other words , if two phase functions locally generate the same lagrangian , then oscillatory integrals   associated to one phase function can be written in the form   using the other phase function as well .",
    "however , the formulas relating even the principal parts of the amplitudes corresponding to different phase functions are quite complicated ; obtaining a geometric interpretation for these formulas is the subject of global theory of lagrangian distributions .",
    "this global theory is needed to produce quantization conditions that we use below ; however , as we are only interested in estimating the resulting eigenfunctions and in some rough properties of the spectrum given by quantization conditions , we do not use the global theory directly .      in this subsection , we assume that @xmath342 is a lagrangian submanifold and @xmath343 .",
    "[ l : generating ] take @xmath344 and denote @xmath345 , where @xmath346 and @xmath347 .",

    "* acknowledgements .",
    "* nb acknowledges partial support from agence nationale de la recherche project anr-07-blan-0250 .",
    "sd and mz acknowledge partial support by the national science foundation under the grant dms-0654436 .",
    "they are also grateful to universit paris - nord for its generous hospitality in the spring 2011 when this paper was written .",
    "r.  morris , r.  najmanovich , a.  kahraman , and j.  thornton , _ real spherical harmonic expansion coefficients as 3d shape descriptors for protein binding pocket and ligand comparison , _ bioinformatics , * 21 * 10 ( 2005 ) , 23472355 ."
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> using tools from semiclassical analysis , we give weighted @xmath0 estimates for eigenfunctions of strictly convex surfaces of revolution . </S>",
    "<S> these estimates give rise to new sampling techniques and provide improved bounds on the number of samples necessary for recovering sparse eigenfunction expansions on surfaces of revolution . on the sphere , our estimates imply that any function having an @xmath1-sparse expansion in the first @xmath2 spherical harmonics can be efficiently recovered from its values at @xmath3 sampling points . </S>"
  ]
}
